Woodward Charitable Trust  The Woodward Charitable Trust favours small-scale  locally based initiatives and primarily one-off projects. They focus on arts  education  environment  disability & health  community and social welfare.    Scheme details  The Woodward Charitable Trust is a grant-making trust and is one of the Sainsbury Family Charitable Trusts. The Trust primarily funds charitable organisations in the UK. If we fund overseas projects it is usually via UK charities which can ensure that funds are being well used. We favour charities which make good use of volunteers and encourage past and current users to participate. The grants we make are for a wide range of activities.    Their current funding priorities include:  ‚Ä¢ Children and young people who are isolated  at risk of exclusion or involved in anti-social behaviour.  ‚Ä¢ Minority groups including refugees  gypsies and travellers. Projects that promote integration and community cohesion will be favoured.  ‚Ä¢ Prisoners and ex-offenders. Projects that help the rehabilitation and resettlement of prisoners and/or ex-offenders are supported as well as requests to help prisoners‚Äô families.  ‚Ä¢ Disability projects  which can include rehabilitation and training for people who are either physically disabled or learning disabled as well as help to improve employment prospects.  ‚Ä¢ Homelessness  especially affecting young people and women  and covering facilities such as women s refuges.  ‚Ä¢ Arts outreach work by local groups involving disadvantaged people.  ‚Ä¢ Environmental projects  especially with a strong educational element.    The Trust prefers to fund small to medium-sized charities with an income of less than ¬£300 000. The majority of our grants are for one-off projects although we may fund salaries and running costs. The Trust receives many more applications than it has funds to support.     For further information  see www.woodwardcharitabletrust.org.uk  or contact@woodwardcharitabletrust.org.uk.

This time last week the team of Transforming Cancer Follow up Macmillan Managers were getting ready to go to London and find out if they d won a Nursing Standard Award for improving cancer aftercare.  Well: they won and here s why.  Read Roy s story:  Roy  75-year-old Roy McCullough from Derry was diagnosed with prostate cancer 12 years ago.  He is one of the many people in Northern Ireland now living with cancer as a long term condition.  Back in 2002  he had to travel to Belfast for two months of intensive treatment  after which he says he felt ‚Äúabandoned‚Äù.  He says cancer care and aftercare has been transformed over the past few years and patients now have more and more support to get back into their normal routine:   ‚ÄúConsultant oncologists aren‚Äôt available at the drop of a hat.  You may only see them once a year.    ‚ÄúThe rest of the time I know now that  if I have any concerns  I can phone my Clinical Nurse Specialist and she‚Äôll talk things through or get things rolling.   ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want anyone thinking I‚Äôm on the phone all the time but knowing there‚Äôs an expert there to talk to is what‚Äôs important.‚Äù  Roy believes the role of Cancer Nurse Specialists is key to the success of the new system of aftercare and has joined a local support group for men going through treatment and living with prostate cancer.

A massive well done to the team at #ShimnaIntegratedCollege  who were recently awarded their OCN Level 2 certificates in Action Cancers  Listening Ear. These amazing young people will now be the new  Ears  for their peers within the school and able to support them emotionally and practically at a time they may need it most.  Action Cancer have now been working with the team for 8 years to provide this accredited training and subsequent service and would like to take this opportunity to thank you again for your ongoing support of the charity.  Pictured with the  Ears  are Aine Harrison and Danella Goodman  the training and assessment team within the school and Elizabeth Boyd  Services Support Officer for Action Cancer.   Well done again!!

A huge thank you to everyone who stepped out to support Saturday s #WinterWoollyWalk! We would love to hear what you thought of the day and would really appreciate it if you could take two minutes to complete the short survey below ...

‚ÄúI was 12 when I first found I had cancer  two weeks before Christmas in 2014. I had a brain tumour so I needed surgery  as well as radiotherapy and chemotherapy.   ‚ÄúBecause of my treatment I couldn‚Äôt do full days in school  but I tried to go as much as possible for the support of my friends and to keep myself positive.   ‚ÄúBecause of where my tumour was  it pressed up against my optic nerves so I have no peripheral vision and I have no depth perception. When I first got diagnosed I was really insecure  I couldn‚Äôt go out by myself  and when friends went out I couldn‚Äôt go because I couldn‚Äôt see properly would feel really nervous.  ‚ÄúWhen I got to meet my Cancer Fund for Children Specialist Caitriona  it was amazing. She‚Äôd take me out and we‚Äôd get coffee or hot chocolate  and just talk about how things were going. I don‚Äôt know where I would be if I hadn‚Äôt had Caitriona to talk to  I wouldn‚Äôt have been as positive.  ‚ÄúWithout your donations  the people who work at these brilliant charities wouldn‚Äôt be there. I know how much I‚Äôve benefitted from Cancer Fund for Children‚Äôs services. Please donate to help these exceptional charities keep doing their life changing work.‚Äù  Your donations can really make a difference to young people like Rebekkah diagnosed with cancer.   Text TEN to 70144 to donate ¬£10 or call 0800 60 50 40 to make your own donation over the phone.   Thank you!  #QRadiothon #TogetherWeCan

We are the Loughrans and we‚Äôre Winter Woolly Walkers because when cancer entered our lives everything changed. My daughter Aislinn missed out on a big part of her childhood. Playing with friends and going to birthday parties was replaced with hospital stays  operations and gruelling treatment regimes. Aislinn is now catching up and making the most of life. We couldn‚Äôt have got here without the support of NICFC which helped Aislinn and her siblings understand what was happening. Cancer is an awful illness and it‚Äôs important to raise awareness of NICFC so people know there is help available. Please join me and sign up to Winter Woolly Walk. Your efforts will help vulnerable families benefit from support services and free short breaks which will enable them to recharge their batteries and spend precious time together.  http://www.nicfc.com/event/winter-woolly-walk-for-daisy-lodge/

Women: Dealing with the Past Tuesday  8 October 2013 The Europa Hotel  Belfast 10.00am ‚Äì 2.00pm Lunch will be provided This workshop will explore women‚Äôs experiences of Peace and how the legacies of the past can unite and divide us as women. Speakers for this event will include Dawn Purvis and Claire Hackett. Dawn  a former MLA  is Chair of Healing Through Remembering  a cross-community organisation working on a common goal of how to deal with the legacy of the past.  Claire Hackett  a community worker at Falls Community Council  has been involved in an oral history archive  D√∫chas  documenting the experiences of the conflict in West Belfast  and is a board member of Hanna‚Äôs House  an all-Ireland women‚Äôs peace building project. Travel within the Greater Belfast area can be arranged for women‚Äôs groups / Women‚Äôs Centres ‚Äì please contact Kelli on 028 9023 0212.  To register for this FREE event: RSVP by Monday 30th September to Shauna: info@wrda.net.

Building Change Trust Civic Activism Programme  The Building Change Trust will launch its Civic Activism Programme on Wednesday  21st January 2015 at the Duncairn Centre for Culture & Arts in Belfast.   This programme aims to give Voluntary  Community and Social Enterprise organisations the opportunity to experiment with innovative approaches to engaging people in decisionmaking processes that impact on their lives.  To enable this  the Trust has compiled a Civic Activism Toolkit which features a directory of 29 innovative tools for civic activism work  drawn from around the world. In addition  the toolkit provides a series of civic activism tips and case studies from local practitioners.  For more information and to register for the event  go to:  http://www.buildingchangetrust.org/events

Free Counselling Service in Limavady/ Derry/Strabane Action Cancer provides counselling to anyone impacted by cancer.  One lady said  Counselling has had a positive impact on all areas of my life over the last 6 months.  I got a safe space to discuss all my difficulties that the diagnosis of cancer raised.  When I first arrived my mental state was low and I was physically weak.  I am now at a good place physically and mentally.  The most positive part of Action Cancer was talking and dealing with issues as they arose through this very difficult period.   If you feel counselling would help you call 028 7127 7123 or 028 9080 3344 for an appointment today.

Are your children struggling to cope with your cancer diagnosis?  Our children s services can help.  We provide free counselling and complementary therapy to children over the age of 5 who have been directly affected by cancer or a parent/close relatives diagnosis.  The services teach children coping mechanisms that help them deal with their emotions. To find out more go to our website www.actioncancer.org  Appointments can be made by calling Action Cancer on 028 9080 3344.

Want to see headline cancer figures in your health trust area?  Check out @macmillancancer Local Cancer Intelligence tool for Northern Ireland http://www.macmillan.org.uk/lci-northern-ireland   Thanks to Macmillan‚Äôs Evidence Department  Northern Ireland now has its own Local Cancer Intelligence (LCI) website created in collaboration with the Northern Ireland Cancer Registry (NICR).   The new LCI toolkit combines Macmillan and NICR data to bring together information on the changing cancer population across Northern Ireland health trusts  councils and tumour groups.    Designed with health service commissioners and cancer care teams in mind  it‚Äôs an easy-to-use  headline view of the key issues  from prevalence to patient experience  and is a great starting point for identifying future needs for local services.  You can access the site on your PC  tablet and mobile.   In the lead up to the Northern Ireland Assembly elections on 5 May  these detailed statistics will allow us influence decision makers and help commissioners ask important questions about cancer within their health trust area.

Gordons Chemists latest fundraising drive helps them smash through the ¬£200K mark in their continuing 8 year partnership!   Staff and customers  have come together once again to raise an incredible ¬£17 274 for Action Cancer throughout 2015  bringing their total raised to date for the charity  to over ¬£200 000.  The continuing partnership between Action Cancer and Gordons Chemists has been a roaring success to date  engaging staff and customers in all sorts of wonderful ways to raise funds over the years  including sponsored cycles  raffles  onesie to work days and of course donned their pink wigs and tutus throughout October  for Breast Cancer Awareness Month.   Gordons Chemists have been huge supporters of both Breast Cancer Awareness Month (through their own Breast Action Day)  and Action Cancer‚Äôs Safe Sun campaign.   #ThankYou #Partnership #Proud #SupportLocal

First World War: then and now  First World War: then and now provides grants of ¬£3 000 to ¬£10 000 for communities to mark the Centenary of the First World War. They also provide grants of more than ¬£10 000 for First World War projects ‚Äì under the Understanding the First World War scheme.  This scheme is designed to make a real difference to a wide range of people by helping them understand the war and its impact better. In particular  they believe that involving young people in marking the Centenary is important. Under this scheme Heritage Lottery Fund expect your project to achieve a minimum of one outcome for people from the list below. It is unlikely that your project will achieve a large number of these outcomes.  Outcomes for people: -learnt about heritage -developed skills -changed their attitudes and/or behaviour -had an enjoyable experience -volunteered time  Outcomes for heritage  -in better condition -better interpreted and explained -identified/recorded  Outcomes for communities  -more people and a wider range of people will have engaged with heritage  How to Apply  For more information please visit:  http://www.hlf.org.uk/HowToApply/programmes/Pages/FirstWorldWarThenandNow.aspx#.Uv0nWvvJ2ok  The next deadline is 28th February 2014 for decision meeting on 28th April 2014  Heritage Lottery Fund - Our Heritage  The Our Heritage programme is for any type of project related to national  regional or local heritage in the UK. You can apply for a grant of more than ¬£10 000 and up to ¬£100 000. Under this programme  they fund applications from not-for-profit organisations  private owners of heritage (including individuals and for-profit organisations) and partnerships. Heritage includes many different things from the past that are valued and passed on to future generations  for example: archaeological sites; collections of objects  books or documents in museums  libraries or archives; cultural traditions such as stories  festivals  crafts  music  dance & costumes; historic buildings; histories of people and communities; histories of places and events; the heritage of languages and dialects; natural and designed landscapes and gardens; people‚Äôs memories and experiences (often recorded as ‚Äòoral history‚Äô); places and objects linked to our industrial  maritime and transport history; and natural heritage including habitats  species and geology.  Application process  Our Heritage is a rolling programme  meaning you can apply anytime. Your application will be assessed in eight weeks and then a decision is made.  For more details on how to apply please visit: www.hlf.org.uk

We re looking forward to a birthday celebration with a big difference at the weekend...  19 year old Bethany Courtney is celebrating the 1 year anniversary of a Bone Marrow Transplant which helped her fight off two rare forms of cancer.  To mark her path to recovery  Bethany and her family are inviting everyone along to her  BMT Birthday Fete  in Edengrove Presbyterian Church  Ballynahinch on Saturday 22nd October  to enjoy a family day out and raise funds for Cancer Fund for Children.  Bethany decided she wanted to mark this milestone anniversary by doing something special for the charity which supported her and her family throughout her treatment.  There s lots of fun for all the family  including bouncy castles  beauty treatments and a Halloween fancy dress competition  with prizes for the best dressed!  To find out more  go to: http://bit.ly/2eBAS3p

Woodland Trust ‚Äì Free Trees to Community Groups and schools   This August marks the 100th anniversary of the outbreak of the First World War and the Woodland Trust would like you to take part in a once-in-a-generation tribute to all those who gave their lives by creating a growing legacy that will stand tall for centuries to come.   Over the next four years they are offering three million free trees to help communities  schools and youth groups remember their local heroes. The Woodland Trust not only want to create a lasting legacy for those involved in World War 1  but also improve their local area - and would like people to get involved while supplies are still available.   Trees are available to schools and local groups such as Scouts  Guides  sports clubs and parish councils  who can apply for a pack via the Woodland Trust website. The Trust is encouraging people to organise tree planting events in their local area as part of its First World War Centenary Woods campaign that aims to see millions of trees planted across the UK.   https://www.woodlandtrust.org.uk/plant-trees/in-your-community/

Action Cancer MOT the MOT guys!   Charles Hurst Toyota and Action Cancer recently announced a yearlong partnership aimed at raising awareness and funds for the charity‚Äôs range of cancer prevention  early detection and support services  As part of our Male Cancer Awareness month this June  Health Promotion Officer  Anne Thompson  performs a blood pressure check on Matthew Morgan  Technician at Charles Hurst Toyota. Heritage Lottery Fund ‚Äì Heritage Enterprise Programme  Heritage Enterprise supports enterprising community organisations across the UK to rescue neglected historic buildings and sites and unlock their economic potential can apply for a grant from ¬£100 000 to ¬£5 million. A Heritage Enterprise grant you can breathe new life into historic sites by repairing  adapting and giving them a productive new use. By funding much of the repair costs the Heritage Lottery Fund hope to encourage private developers to work with community organisations to deliv-er commercially viable schemes.  For more information on the programme and how to apply please visit:   www.hlf.org.uk/HowToApply/programmes/Pages/Heritage_Enterprise.aspx#.UuYpQhdFDIV The next deadline is Thursday 10 December 2015 for a decision in March 2016.

Cancer doesn‚Äôt care about children but we do.    Please vote for Cancer Fund for Children to receive a ¬£5 000 Christmas gift from Danske Bank so we can help families like Molly Taylor‚Äôs from Ahoghill.    http://www.danskebank.co.uk/en-gb/About-the-bank/corporate-responsibility/Society/Pages/christmas-charity-gift.aspx  Molly was diagnosed with a brain tumour in 2014  and since then her family have been benefitting from a range of specialist support from Cancer Fund for Children. PUBLICATION OF THE CHILDREN AND YOUNG PEOPLE ‚ÄôS STRATEGIC INDICATORS UPDATE SEPTEMBER 2013  Office of the First Minister And Deputy First Minister  The ten year strategy for children and young people ‚ÄòOur Children and Young People ‚Äì Our Pledge‚Äô was published in 2006.   The Children and Young People‚Äôs Strategic Indicators as published  link to the strategic outcomes contained in the strategy. The outcomes are: healthy; economic and environmental well-being; enjoying  learning and achieving; positive and valued contribution; and  living in safety and stability. The purpose of the indicators is to measure the success of the strategy over time  the baseline for the majority of the indicators being set at 2004 or 2005.  The report is available on the OFMDFM Research Branch website at: www.ofmdfmni.gov.uk/index/equality-and-strategy/pfg-economics-statistics/equalityresearch/research-publications/esn-pubs/equality-publications-2013.htm

The Ulster Farmers  Union President Barclay Bell has encouraged people from rural communities to support Macmillan Cancer Support s first Cancer Experience Panel in Northern Ireland.  Ulster Farmers‚Äô Union President Barclay Bell said  ‚ÄúWe would like to encourage our members in rural communities to support Macmillan Cancer Support‚Äôs first Cancer Experience Panel in Northern Ireland. It is important to hear the voices of people in rural areas to help shape services in our farming communities. All too often it is those in rural areas who are under-represented. If you have been affected by cancer  or are a carer of someone who has cancer  perhaps you would consider putting your name forward for the Cancer Experience Panel.‚Äù  Further information (including a full role description  application form and FAQ document) is available for anyone interested in the role. At the most challenging and difficult times for families  I have witnessed the unbelievable strength  hope and determination which continues to inspire me on a daily basis to do as much as I can with and for all the families we support.   Meet Neil  he is one of Cancer Fund for Children‚Äôs Community Specialists.  He works with families across Northern Ireland who are facing the devastating impact of a childhood cancer diagnosis.  Childhood cancer and its treatment can often lead to a multitude of challenges and issues for children and young people.  These include feelings of isolation  lack of confidence  negative body image  fear and anxiety.   Specialists like Neil provide exercises  activities  visits  discussions and space  whereby children and young people can begin to explore these issues and develop resilience  confidence and skills so they are better equipped to deal with their challenges going forward.    September is Childhood Cancer Awareness Month #CCAM to find out more about the support Specialists like Neil provide to young people affected by cancer visit:  http://bit.ly/2c3Q8PX

Every Thursday evening you will find our Specialists on the ward of the Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children and last week Specialist Michelle got to grips with some jewellery making! Missing family and friends coupled with feelings of loneliness  boredom and fear are just some of the challenges facing the children and young people we support when they have to spend time as an inpatient. Cancer Fund for Children Specialists are there to help alleviate this by providing one to one and group support on the ward  creating fun activities that take young minds off treatment ahead. To find out more about how we help visit: http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/how-we-help/

First Minister the Rt. Hon. Peter D. Robinson  MLA and Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness  MLA have announced the first projects to be funded through the Social Investment Fund (SIF) programme  ¬£33million will be invested in 12 capital projects and 11 revenue projects  aimed at tackling poverty and deprivation through improved community based services and facilities. The First Minister  Peter Robinson said: ‚ÄúI welcome this ¬£33million investment in projects to deliver the Social Investment Fund programme. An enormous amount of work has been done by Steering Groups to identify projects that will address the issues affecting the communities that are most in need in each area.  Today‚Äôs announcement of the first 23 projects confirms where almost half of the Social Investment Fund will be spent. We are determined to see all ¬£80million of this important fund allocated in the coming months.‚Äù  The listed projects have been identified as priorities by Steering Groups in each zone.  Letters of offer will be issued to the successful projects following completion of verification and governance checks which are now taking place.Work is continuing to bring forward further projects which are expected to be ready to start later this year.  The Deputy First Minister Martin McGuinness said: ‚ÄúThrough the Steering Groups local people have identified and prioritised the areas of need to ensure the maximum impact of the overall ¬£80million Social Investment Fund.  This is only the start and I am confident this funding will enable groups to deliver real benefits for people on the ground. The funding will result in jobs  training and improved facilities for many of the hardest hit areas of our community.‚Äù  A list of projects to be offered funding is available at:   http://www.northernireland.gov.uk/index/media-centre/news-departments/news-ofmdfm/news-ofmdfm-100214-robinson-andmcguinness.htm

During Childhood Cancer Month we wanted to share the story of a 15 year old who has a brain tumour and has used our complementary therapy services to help her cope with the symptoms.  ‚ÄúLauren had very poor energy levels  hormonal problems  dry skin and back pain. As a result of the complementary therapy her anxiety levels have definitely reduced as she sleeps much better. She feels very relaxed during and after the sessions and is able to talk openly about her worries and fears. The combination of back and body massage and reflexology has really helped and her condition has definitely improved. Many thanks Action Cancer for providing this wonderful service ‚Äì it has helped us so much during a very difficult time  (Yvonne Monaghan  mum).   To avail of our complementary therapy or counselling services for children and young people (aged 5+) please call Action Cancer on 028 9080 3344.

HOUSING RIGHTS SERVICE  Housing Rights Service has great learning and events programmes over the next few months that will ensure you are prepared for all the developments in housing llaw and practice in NI.  On the 14th February 2014  they are running a lunchtime seminar on the impact of negative Vequity proceedings in recent cases from the Chancery.  Other courses include the new Pre Action Protocols to be taken before a possession order reaches court  the bedroom tax in NI  the new landlord registration scheme to be implemented in February 2014 and the Housing Selection Scheme.  They are also excited to run their first Housing Law Update event. This will be an annual event that will provide you with the must have information on key housing policy developments over the past year.  Full information on all these courses is available at: http://bit.ly/JoQt1u

‚ÄúThey will run the equivalent of THREE marathons in ONE day  challenging their minds and bodies like never before‚Äù   Alan Ladd from Mallusk has set himself one heck of a challenge in memory of his mother who died from cancer aged 59 in August 2014. On Saturday 24th June  Alan  his brother Jonny and a team of 7 of his running club mates from Mallusk Harriers will tackle all 24 of Northern Ireland‚Äôs 5k parkrun routes in 24 hours. Starting at Derry City at 9.30am  the team will work their way North  East  South and West of the country  all being well  concluding by 9.30am on Sunday 25th June at Lakeland Forum  Enniskillen.    The team will travel from one end of Northern Ireland to the other and encompass every parkrun course in between. The start-stop nature of the running will pose the guys a massive challenge  making it much harder than a straight 80 mile run. You can support Alan & the team in their quest of raising ¬£10 000 through this challenge by sponsoring him at https://mydonate.bt.com/fundraisers/24in24  Follow their journey at www.24in24.run

Meet Ryan Scott. Ryan is a Housekeeper at our self-catering Cottages in Coleraine. Our Cottages  located close to the River Bann  provide a private haven to families  away from the stresses of cancer  hospital visits and treatment.  Ryan‚Äôs role is to ensure the Cottages are kept clean  safe and comfortable for families who want to enjoy a short break away with their family.  Speaking about his role  Ryan said:  ‚ÄúThe most rewarding part of my job is the satisfaction of working hard to make a family s experience so special. The Cottages are a brilliant facility in a beautiful setting in Coleraine  there s even a lovely coffee shop right next door. What makes It is particularly rewarding when a family have enjoyed their short break and it has helped them create wonderful memories.‚Äù  By supporting our #SummerAppeal you could help a family like Karen‚Äôs affected by cancer enjoy a free self-catering short break at one of our Cottages in Coleraine.  Karen‚Äôs family were able to enjoy their first family holiday together at the Cottages. Karen was reassured that the Cottages were safe and clean  giving them peace of mind whilst Tom was still in cancer treatment.  Just ¬£50 could help pay for a family‚Äôs self-catering short break  giving them the opportunity to spend quality time together.  Please give whatever you can today: bit.ly/SummerAppeal  Read more of Ryan‚Äôs story: http://bit.ly/2souRNi  #SummerAppeal #ShortBreaks #ChildhoodCancerAwareness #Donate

It‚Äôs Winter Woolly Walk month! Preparations are well underway for our eight Winter Woolly Walks taking place at the end of the month.   Over the coming weeks  we‚Äôll be featuring some of the beautiful locations where we hope you will join us with your family for a fresh winter walk.   First up are our walks in Portstewart  Derry/Londonderry and Enniskillen.   Starting and finishing at Harry‚Äôs Shack  the Portstewart walk sweeps along the picturesque North Coast and takes in the views of Inishowen Headland and Mussenden Temple perched atop the cliffs.   The walk in Derry/Londonderry starts at St Columb‚Äôs Park House and takes in the beautiful surroundings of Ebrington Square and the iconic Peace bridge.   Finally  the walk in Castle Coole  Enniskillen starts at the Grand Yard and passes the Ice-House  before taking in breath-taking views of the lake  mansion and surrounding countryside.   All walks are around 3-4 miles  and are followed by warming refreshments and family fun.   To join us  go to: http://bit.ly/WinterWoollyWalk

Lylehill Young Farmers Club held their 85th Anniversary Dinner in the Dunadry Hotel on Friday 20th February! The club would like to thank the Dunadry Hotel and their Guest Speaker YFCU Vice President James Speers! The Dinner rounded off a year of celebrations which included a Tractor Run in memory of past Club Leader  past President and long serving Patron  Trustee and friend Jamesie Watt. This event raised ¬£2 495 for Northern Ireland Chest  Heart and Stroke. Other fundraising events throughout the year included bagpacks  fireside quizzes  a treasure hunt and cycling 85 miles around Lough Neagh! Through these events ¬£8 223.80 was raised for Macmillan Cancer Support  bringing the total donated to charity in Lylehill YFC‚Äôs 85th year to a staggering ¬£10 718.80! THANK YOU TO ALL WHO TOOK PART!

Promoting Integration Award Social integration  positive interaction and community cohesion ‚Äì some of the things the Chartered Institute of Housing think are worth celebrating! The Promoting Integration Award recognises housing-related initiatives that encourage integration of communities  whether in terms of age  ethnicity  religion  disability  economic status  housing tenure or other status. The Award is open for nominations of initiatives involving housing providers  professionals or community groups which promote shared spaces  increase positive interactions across communities or make meaningful contributions to community life.  So if you are proud of what your organisation does or impressed with what others have achieved  nominate them now at www.cih.org/ni/awards and help the Chartered Institute of Housing find the winner for one of their 2014 Housing Awards.  Don‚Äôt delay as the application deadline is Monday 16 December 2013. Full details of the 10 award categories and how to apply are outlined on the awards website.  If you have any questions or require further information about how to submit your nomination please contact Kerry Kelly by email: kerry.kelly@cih.org or by telephone on 028 9077 8222.

Invest NI‚Äôs Social Entrepreneurship Programme is now open for applications    The Social Entrepreneurship Programme is a free initiative that has been developed to help voluntary  community and social economy sector organisations develop a profitable enterprise that will provide an unrestricted source of income and ensure the future sustainability of your organisation.     This is achieved through a programme of free  specialist one to one mentoring. Funding assistance may also be offered depending on the economic benefits of the social enterprise. Applications for this programme are open.     To find out more about the Social Enterprise model or about the Social Entrepreneurship Programme itself visit www.enterprisenw.com or email brian@enterprisenw.com for further information or to discuss the application process.

MEET LAUREN   I was diagnosed with Thyroid Cancer in 2014 when I was 16. My family and close friends were extremely supportive but if the peer mentoring service was around when I was going through treatment I would have felt a lot less alone and isolated being the age I was  and going on with school and exams. Hopefully I can help someone through their cancer journey even if it s just by being there to listen.    Lauren is part of our Peer Mentoring Team at Action Cancer who have all had their own cancer diagnosis and who are now keen to share their experiences in such a way that it may help others along a similar journey  by listening  sharing stories  answering questions and just being there in a way that sometimes others can‚Äôt be.   If you would like to get in touch with Lauren or any of our mentors  please contact Elizabeth Boyd on 90803355/07580133757 or at eboyd@actioncancer.org

Little Ben Herbert (6) who was diagnosed with leukaemia last year got on-board to help promote the Light it up Gold campaign with MLA Steven Agnew at Stormont. As part of the parent-led LIUG campaign  which was warmly supported by NICFC  buildings across Ireland including Castle Buildings and Belfast City Hall were lit up in gold last week to raise awareness of childhood cancer.  NICFC‚Äôs Director of Services Liz Osborne congratulated all those involved in making LIUG the resounding success it has been. She added: ‚ÄúMany people rallied behind this inspiring initiative. Thanks must go to all the parents and their children who participated in LIUG. A big thank you also to parents from across Ireland who reached out and invited NICFC to share this unique experience. It was our pleasure to do so.‚Äù

EUROSPAR NI and ViVOXTRA NI bag ¬£750 000 for local children with cancer.   We are absolutely to delighted to announce that Henderson Group  owners of EUROPSPAR and ViVOXTRA have reached a phenomenal fundraising milestone of ¬£750K for Cancer Fund for Children.   The local community supermarkets have been supporting us for six years  with staff and customers raising this staggering total through a wide range of fundraising events  from in-store collections and coffee mornings to overseas treks and local challenge events.   The funds raised will help us ensure children and young people living with cancer in Northern Ireland don‚Äôt have to face it alone.   Find out more at cancerfundforchildren.com

BBC Children in Need - Main Grants Programme    The Main Grants programme is open to charities and not-for-profit organisations applying for grants over ¬£10 000 per year for up to three years.   Funding is available to not-for-profit organisations in the UK that are supporting children and young people of 18 years and under who are experiencing disadvantage through:    ÔÇ∑  -Illness  distress  abuse or neglect   -Any kind of disability   -Behavioural or psychological difficulties   -Living in poverty or situations of deprivation    Organisations must be working to combat this disadvantage and to make a real difference to children and young people s lives.   Grants of over ¬£10 000 are available to support projects for up to three years.  There is no upper limit but very few grants over ¬£100 000 are made and most grants are for much less.    Deadlines: 19th January 2017  15th May 2017 and 15th September 2017   For further information  visit www.bbc.co.uk/pudsey

This #VolunteersWeek we met up with Lynnette  our adventurous volunteer who began volunteering back in 2013 when she embarked on a trek to China: ‚ÄúI lost my granddad at a very young age to cancer and I know the devastating affect this disease has on the family. This is one of the reasons Cancer Fund for Children means so much to me. Seeing the help they provide and hearing just how much it means to the families they support is a very humbling experience. When you start volunteering you realise it is like a little family.  Everyone knows each other  and many have been volunteering for years.‚Äù Lynette is calling for others to get involved too: ‚ÄúI would simply say stop thinking and just do it. You‚Äôll not be sorry that you have.  Why would you not when all you have to do is donate some of your time. It costs you nothing but in turn helps a fantastic charity to do some wonderful things for families going through such a tough time.‚Äù Read more: http://bit.ly/1Og15QQ

We would like to congratulate the team of staff and volunteers from Belfast HSC Trust who recently received their Foundation Skills in Listening Ear certificates  accredited at level 2 by Open College Network. 14 people completed the course and pictured are Patsy McDaniel  (Macmillan Locality Volunteer Co-Ordinator)   Maureen Moore (volunteer  Macmillan)  Janet Morrison (Centre Manager  Macmillan) Maressa Anthony (OT  Macmillan)  Marese McGibbon (social worker)  Elizabeth Boyd (Services Support Officer  Action Cancer)  and Maggie O‚ÄôReilly ( Community Oncology Sister).  The course enhances current listening and support skills and encourages participants to focus on the emotional support that those affected by a cancer diagnosis may need. Those completing this programme are also given the opportunity to complete the Train The Trainer in Listening Ear skills (OCN level 3) which means they can cascade Listening Ear training to others working or volunteering in cancer services within the BHSCT.  Anyone who has previously completed this training course with Action Cancer and who would like to be considered as potential trainer  should contact Elizabeth on eboyd@actioncancer.org or telephone 028 9080 3355.‚Äù

Youth in Action Programme Information Morning TUESDAY 3 SEPTEMBER 2013 10.30AM - 1.00PM Grosvenor House  Glengall Street  Belfast For all Voluntary and Community partnerships or groups - send your key representatives to this Information Morning to learn from the Youth Council for Northern Ireland (the UK National Agency s Information Provider for the programme in Northern Ireland)  about how you can access this valuable gateway to EU funding. The programme awards grants to groups of young people  individuals and youth workers who want to take advantage of a range of options including:  Youth Exchanges  Youth Initiatives Projects  Youth Democracy Projects  Job Shadowing  Volunteering Opportunities  Creating opportunities for young people to meet with policymakers Organisations  youth workers and young people in Northern Ireland have benefited from opportunities gained through participation in the programme  to explore locally  or share with their peers from other countries; youth work practice and concepts such as participation  active citizenship  cultural diversity and inclusion. Light refreshments will be available For registration forms contact: andrew.johnston@dsdni.gov.uk   T: 028 9082 9368

We would like to say a HUGE thank you to our wonderful Ambassador Inez.  Since Inez first started her annual tractor run in 2013 in aid of Action Cancer she has raised a phenomenal ¬£32 883!!  Inez had her breast cancer detected at Action Cancer in 2011 and since then has become a wonderful Ambassador for us  encouraging women aged 40-49 and 70+ to book a breast screening with us  as well as raising valuable funds for our breast screening service.   When hit with this kind of news you have to look at it as a hurdle in life  a mountain to climb but something that you can get over. For me  keeping positive helped enormously. You can‚Äôt bury your head in the sand - you ought to be proactive about your health. I was  and Action Cancer helped to save my life.‚Äù  Thank you Inez!

Are you a parent/guardian of a child or young person who is affected by cancer?  Action Cancer  in partnership with the Science Shop at the Ulster University  is carrying out research to explore how information about support services is communicated to young people affected by cancer.    From this research we hope to develop more effective ways of communicating this information. This research is part of a Dissertation for a student completing BSc Communication.  We are inviting parents of young people affected by cancer to participate in this research. If you decide to participate  you will be asked to attend a focus group (small group discussion) to discuss parental needs when caring for your child.    The focus group will provide you with the opportunity to give your views on the issues that are most pertinent to you as parents/guardians.  In doing so  it is hoped that a number of views can be considered when trying to improve the care of young people both with a cancer diagnosis and those affected by cancer.  We plan to hold the focus groups at Action Cancer House  1 Marlborough Park  Belfast between 6pm and 8pm on 17th and 24th February 2015.  If you are interested in taking part  or would like more information  please contact Dr Caroline Hughes at Action Cancer on 02890803344 or email chughes@actioncancer.org  or Niall Connor on 07935639937 or email nconnor1989@gmail.com.  * Focus groups will be recorded for analysis. All recordings and data collected from these focus groups will be handled with strict confidentiality  in adherence to the ‚ÄòData Protection Act‚Äô (1998).  Thank you.

Patients  families and carers:  tell us what you think about end of life care The  Let‚Äôs Talk About  survey is the first of its kind across Ireland and continues until the end of May. The survey can be completed online at www.letstalk-about.org. The survey asks people with illnesses which may not be cured to share their experiences  both good and bad. This includes people living with conditions such as cancer  advanced respiratory disease  chronic kidney disease  heart failure or dementia. The survey is being led by the All Ireland Institute of Hospice and Palliative Care (AIIHPC) with support from the Public Health Agency (PHA) and Health Service Executive (HSE) in the Republic of Ireland. Responses are confidential and take 15-20 minutes to complete

THE CONFERENCE OF THE ISLES  The Bright Brand New Day Housing Conference  Everglades Hotel  28th - 29th November 2013  Derry-Londonderry  UK City of Culture 2013  About the Conference  Government spending plans across the United Kingdom and Ireland will be a key driver for  change in the coming period impacting on organisations  households and local communities.  Whilst change may present many challenges for housing professionals and communities   opportunities will arise to embrace pioneering and innovative ways of working.  This conference aims to consider the key questions and themes that will shape the future of  housing and communities locally and nationally. In particular  it will provide an open forum for  discussion among all the key stakeholders with an interest in housing innovations.  The Conference will be of interest to:  q Housing Professionals and Practitioners  q Housing Association Board Members  q Local Government Representatives  q Private Landlords and Developers  q Letting Agents  q Policy Makers and Government Officials  q Financial Institutions  q Voluntary and Community Sector Organisations  q Academics and Housing Students  q Financial Institutions  Full programming details will be available soon but register your interest to get updates on The  Conference of the Isles.  To register  go to:  http://www.bigbrightstar.com/current-events/Conference-of-the-Isles/Index.html

Parks for People  Parks for People is for projects related to historic parks and cemeteries in the UK.   You can apply for a grant from ¬£100 000 to ¬£5million.  HLF must receive your first-round application and all supporting documents by 12pm on:  1st September for a decision in December 29th February for a decision in June  The same deadlines apply to second-round applications and supporting documents. These must be received up to 26 months after the first round decision.  Contact for more info-  Una Duffy / Jamie Curran  Development Officer Heritage Lottery Fund (Northern Ireland)  51-53 Adelaide Street  Belfast BT2 8FE Telephone: 028 9031 0120 Email: northernireland@hlf.org.uk

24 year old Megan Boyd was diagnosed with cancer on 17th April  2014.   ‚ÄúIt all happened very quickly  I went to my Doctors at 10am that morning and at 2pm that day I was getting chemotherapy.  ‚ÄúAfter a month of chemotherapy I went in to remission. I was due to go for a bone marrow transplant but unfortunately I relapsed just before I was due to go - you have to be in remission to get a transplant.  ‚ÄúUnfortunately I found out that the type of cancer I had was now immune to the chemotherapy treatment I was on.   ‚ÄúSo my only option was to go to London to try a new trial drug that opened up. My mum had to quit work and we both went to stay in London for three months to undergo this new treatment. Thankfully it worked and I went in to remission and was eventually able to get my transplant.  ‚ÄúCancer Fund for Children were amazing support to me during that time. They helped us financially  providing us with a grant to help my family with the costs of travelling to hospital  and to London for treatment.  ‚ÄúThey also supported me emotionally. I was able to go to Daisy Lodge and spend time with other young people who were going through the same thing. Whilst I was in hospital for treatment  I was isolated and never got to see other young people so it was great to be able to talk to other people who knew what it was like to have cancer.‚Äù  Megan is bravely opening up about her experience with cancer to encourage local people to do what they can to support families just like hers.   You can help make a difference today by signing up to give a regular monthly donation of just ¬£5 a month.   http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/donate/  Thank you. #Gimme5 #RegularGiving #SupportingYoungPeople

This March hair and beauty salons right across Northern Ireland will sign up to take part in the Super Salon Challenge!  Will I wear my hair up  down  straight or curly? These are the kind of questions women look in the mirror and ask themselves on a daily basis. Our hair is an accessory  a comfort blanket... our identity. So what happens when women are faced with losing their hair due to cancer treatment?   Listen to Action Cancer‚Äôs ambassador Sandra McCarry tell her inspirational story in support of the Super Salon Challenge!   If your salon would like to get involved with our Super Salon Challenge Contact Action Cancer on 028 9080 3344 for your fundraising pack!   Tag your hair or beauty salon and encourage them to sign up to this amazing challenge in support of women across Northern Ireland OR if you‚Äôre inspired by Sandra‚Äôs story you can click the link and make a donation: https://www.justgiving.com/campaigns/charity/actioncancer/supersalonchallenge

‚ÄúThis programme was made available to me through Cancer Fund for Children when I would not have had the means to do it anywhere in my community  it has spring boarded me to strive to be the best that I can be. The hard times  well the times we got lost only made me re-evaluate everything and when I looked around at the group I knew together  after everything we had been through in our lives  we could get through this!‚Äù   Conquer Slieve Donard on Sunday 28th May  and help local young people  affected by cancer conquer their own personal mountains.  By taking on Northern Ireland‚Äôs highest peak  you could help support young people who are struggling to cope with the impact of a parental cancer diagnosis.  Young people who have a parent diagnosed with cancer are often under enormous stress in their young lives ‚Äì from worrying about loved ones to taking on extra responsibilities such as housework and caring for siblings  in addition to their own school work.  Funds raised through the Slieve Donard Climb could for example provide these young people  like the one quoted above  with the unique opportunity of completing their Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award.  As part of this Award  young people affected by cancer will learn a new skill  volunteer their time to help others as well as demonstrate physical ability and team work by taking on expeditions in the outdoors  some of which often take place in the Mourne Mountains.  Through the support of Cancer Fund for Children and the Duke of Edinburgh Programme  these young people can push their own boundaries  make new friendships and learn how to receive and give support to other young people going through the same thing as them.  To sign up to climb Slieve Donard  go to: bit.ly/ClimbSlieveDonard

CHARITY REGULATOR URGES CHARITIES TO PREPARE FOR REGISTRATION    In preparation for the beginning of charity registration later this year  the Charity Commission for Northern Ireland is advising all charitable organisations to check if they are  on one of the Commission‚Äôs registration lists and if they are not yet on one of the three registration lists  there are a number of steps they need to take to ensure the Commission calls them forward to apply for charity registration.    The Commission has created three registration lists with each containing a directory of organisations which will be called forward to register. The three lists are:    -Deemed list: organisations registered with Her Majesty‚Äôs Revenue and Customs (HMRC) for charitable tax exemptions by 19th August 2013. This list is set in law and cannot be changed  or added to. This list is available on the Commission‚Äôs website www.charitycommissionni.org.uk     -Non-deemed list: all other charitable organisations  whether long or newly established  which are not registered with HMRC. Organisations will be added to this list as they come forward.    -Special circumstances list: organisations which have made a case to have their application brought forward or have been placed on this list by the Commission. Organisations can only be added to this list by the Commission.    The Commission will call forward organisations from each of the three lists in set tranches over the coming years  ensuring that registration can be managed in a fair and efficient manner.  In order to ensure your organisation will be called forward  the Commission would therefore urge all charities in Northern Ireland to check the online deemed list and undertake one of the  following actions  as appropriate:    If you are on the deemed list and the details are correct - you don‚Äôt need to take any action at this stage. The Commission will be in touch with you regarding registration in due course.    In the future  you will be able to check the Commission‚Äôs website to see which tranche you will be called forward in.    -If you are on the deemed list but the details are incorrect‚Äì please update the Charity Commission by emailing your organisation‚Äôs name  the information to be updated and your contact details to admin@charitycommissionni.org.uk.    -If you are not on the deemed list but you think you held charitable tax status granted by HMRC before 19th August 2013 ‚Äì please email admin@charitycommissionni.org.uk with your charity name  contact name  telephone number  postal address  email address   HMRC reference number and the approximate date on which charitable tax status was granted.    -If you are not on the deemed list and you were granted charitable tax status by HMRC after 19th August 2013 ‚Äì please complete the online Expression of intent form to provide your details to the Commission enabling you to be called forward to apply for charity  registration.    -If you are not on the deemed list and have never applied for charitable tax status by HMRC ‚Äì please complete the online Expression of intent form to provide your details to the  Commission enabling you to be called forward to apply for charity registration.    -If you think there are special circumstances which will apply to your registration - for example you think you are one of a number of similar organisations that could be assessed as a grouped registration or you need to use a particular power set out in the Charities Act for which registration is a condition.     Please complete the online Expression of intent form   outlining any special circumstances which you think apply in your case.    For more information on charity registration and to check the deemed list please visit the Charity  Commission for Northern Ireland‚Äôs website www.charitycommissionni.org.uk

WOODWARD CHARITABLE TRUST  The Trust favours small-scale  locally based initiatives and primarily one off projects. They focus on arts  education  environment  disability and health community and social welfare.   Their current funding priorities are:  -Children and young people who are isolated  at risk of exclusion or involved in anti-social behaviour -Minority groups  projects that promote integration and community cohesion -Prisoners and ex- offenders -Disability projects which include rehabilitation and training for people who are either physically disabled or learning disabled as well as help to improve employment prospects -Homelessness  especially affecting young people and women -Arts outreach work by local groups involving disadvantaged people -Environmental projects  especially with a strong educational element  The Trust prefers to fund small to medium sized charities with an income of less than ¬£300 000 the majority of their grants are for one off projects although they may fund salaries and running costs.  For further information visit ‚Äì   www.woodwardcharitabletrust.org.uk

Allocations Research    In 2012  the Minister for Social Development announced a fundamental review of social housing  allocations in Northern Ireland  delivering on a commitment set out in his Housing  Strategy and Facing the Future Action Plan. Independent research was commissioned and three reports  prepared by the Universities of Ulster and Cambridge  have been published  providing the academics‚Äô views on the future of social housing allocations .     To download the reports  go to:     http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/social-housing-allocations-report1.pdf     The deadline for comments on the reports is Tuesday 4th March 2014.     Comments can be submitted by: Email: allocations@dsdni.gov.uk or in writing to:     Dr Heloise Brown    Department for Social Development    Housing Division   1 Cromac Place    Gasworks Business Park    Ormeau Road.  Belfast   BT7 2JB.

When Joan McCartney retired from her job three years ago  the last thing she wanted to do was sit about the house. Instead she decided to put the valuable skills she‚Äôd learned through her working life to good use and became a lead volunteer for a Community Helper Scheme with Macmillan. As lead volunteer Joan does a bit of everything  from interviewing  training and mentoring new volunteers  right through to leading the team in the community helping out with housework and befriending. Having initially started out looking after the Bangor and Newtownards area  Joan now refers to herself as a ‚Äòfloating lead volunteer‚Äô as she has since taken on looking after schemes in North and West Belfast too. A member of the Volunteer Forum  Joan transmits the views of volunteers back to Macmillan  she also proof reads new information literature and is also an ambassador for the charity. Last year Joan was awarded the Richard Hambro award in recognition for all her efforts for Macmillan in Northern Ireland. Joan feels that volunteering gives her a great focus  as well as getting her out and about meeting new people in lots of different places. If you could spare a few hours a week to help someone living near you  contact Grainne or Sarah at dvsni@macmillan.org.uk or call 028 9070 8610.

Community Relations Council  Core Funding Scheme 17/18 now open  The Core Funding Scheme contributes towards the salary and running costs of organisations which are considered to have strategic importance in delivering community relations programmes in Northern Ireland. The organisations and the nature of work which has been previously supported are publicised in the Councils annual report. Examples of these include peace and reconciliation organisations; mediation and conflict transformation training; community arts based CR programmes; church-based work on reconciliation themes and interface projects. Please contact the Core Funding Officer fdennison@nicrc.org.uk  if you require any further information on this grant scheme.  Please note there is now only one submission date for all applications.   The closing date for all applications is Friday 4th Nov 2016 at 4pm.   Applications received (even by one minute) after the deadline will not be accepted  - See more at: http://www.community-relations.org.uk/funding-posts/media-grant-scheme/#sthash.IEcqBcB7.dpuf

HAVE YOU HAD CANCER AND WOULD LIKE TO HELP OTHERS FACING THIS?  We are now recruiting for our next group of peer mentors who will be supporting those affected by a cancer diagnosis. Our mentoring service aims to offer support to people at all stages of their cancer journey  be it diagnosis  treatment or simply adjusting to life afterwards  by matching clients to someone who has already been there. This unique service means people can talk to someone who has a very real understanding of the emotions  the concerns and the support that is needed when faced with a diagnosis.   All our mentors receive accredited training to allow them to feel secure and confident in their role and ongoing support is provided both informally and formally. The training for this group will be at Action Cancer House  Belfast on the following dates:  Information & Selection Evening  Wednesday 9th September          6.00-7.30  Training Wed 16th September                       6.00-7.30 Sat 19th September                         10.00-2.30 Wed 23rd September                      6.00-9.00 Sat 26th September                         10.00-2.30 Wed 30th September                      6.00 9.00  If this is something you are interested in  please contact Elizabeth Boyd on eboyd@actioncancer.org or 028 9080 3355.

Paul  has been working in kitchens since he was 13  nurturing a deeply rooted passion for cooking with local  seasonal produce. It is this love for the larder of Northern Ireland that informs his style of cookery today   Good Food From The Heart . Having worked in many of the restaurants around his foodie hometown of Dundrum  Paul finally received acclaim for his tenure as Head Chef of the Dundrum Inn where he was awarded the Taste Of Northern Ireland award in 2012. Brunel s opened in 2014 and has been steadily making its mark on the food landscape of Northern Ireland ever since  with the Sunday Life naming it their Number 1 restaurant of 2015. Now a permanent fixture on any foodies tour of NI  Brunel s is synonymous with the very best in modern Irish cuisine. Read more: http://bit.ly/DWAD16   Kindly supported by Food NI

The Charles Hayward Foundation  The Foundation will fund capital costs  project funding may be offered for start- up or development activities where these are not part of the on-going requirement of the organisation.  Emphasis is placed on funding projects that are innovative or developmental.  We also value projects that are preventative or provide early intervention.  The small grant scheme makes grants up to ¬£5000.  There is no application form  your initial application will be made in writing to Dorothy Napierala.  For further details please check the website ‚Äì www.charleshaywardfoundation.org.uk The Board meet four times a year and you may have to wait several months before hearing a response.

It‚Äôs Time to Deliver a cancer strategy for Northern Ireland. Too many people with cancer are struggling to cope with emotional  financial and physical problems that can last long after their treatment ends.  This is only going to get worse as the number of people with cancer is set to rise - but you can help. Join our Time to Deliver campaign and ask the Health Minister and Committee to pledge their support for a cancer strategy in the new Programme for Government. We are absolutely delighted that EUROSPAR NI and ViVOXTRA NI will once again be hosting their Community Coffee Morning this March. Meet 6 year old Thomas from Limavady who designed his very own superhero shield  during a one to one session with his Specialist Neil  to keep him strong and protected during treatment. Thomas‚Äô mum Gillian said; ‚ÄúThomas was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia last November and afterwards he became quite withdrawn and nervous about hospital. His emotional well-being started to become a concern for me. When I first received a call from Cancer Fund for Children I had no idea what a Community Specialist was but then Neil came to our home and told us all about the support Cancer Fund for Children provides and we arranged for Neil to visit Thomas over an initial six sessions. Neil pitched all his visits to him based on his favourite things - dinosaurs and super heroes! It was amazing to see them have so much fun and the sessions were also cleverly designed to get him to talk about his illness in a light hearted way.‚Äù Read more: http://bit.ly/22lxtUv

We‚Äôre absolutely delighted that Lisburn & Castlereagh City Council s newly elected Mayor  Councillor Uel Mackin  has announced has chosen Cancer Fund for Children as his official Mayoral Charity for his year in Office.  During the year  the Mayor‚Äôs Office will be organising and hosting a wide range of fundraising events and is hopeful that local residents and businesses will consider supporting Cancer Fund for Children for any fundraising events organised within the local community.  Speaking about his reasons for selecting Cancer Fund for Children  Councillor Uel Mackin said:  ‚ÄúUnfortunately  cancer has affected nearly all extended families in Northern Ireland and while it is a diagnosis we all dread  the added shock and cruelty of a cancer diagnosis for a child is impossible for us to imagine. I wanted to use my time as Mayor to do whatever I can to make that pain even a little more bearable.  I have been continually amazed and humbled by the ongoing generosity of the people of Lisburn & Castlereagh and hope that through working with Cancer Fund For Children we can all dig deep into our pockets and make a real difference to the lives of young people affected by cancer and their families  here in Northern Ireland.‚Äù  To find out more  go to: https://cancerfundforchildren.com/lisburn-castlereagh-city-council-mayors-charity/

Just when the caterpillar thought the world was over  it turned in to a butterfly   A group of young people aged 12-17 diagnosed with cancer recently attended a residential at our residential centre  Narnia.  The young people enjoyed a range of activities designed to increase their confidence  connect them with other young people  build their resilience and of course  have fun.  As part of the residential  the young people used images taken at a local butterfly house to illustrate and express their feelings around transformation and change  something many of them are experiencing as a result of their treatment.  As you can see from these photos  it definitely looks an amazing time was had by all.  #ResidentialSupport #Transformation #SupportingYoungPeople

Northern Ireland Road Safety Grant Scheme   Provided by the Department of the Environment (DOE)  the Road Safety Grant scheme aims to reduce the number of people killed or seriously injured on the roads in Northern Ireland. Since 2010  the scheme has awarded more than ¬£600 000 to 75 projects.  Individuals can only apply for funding if they are working in partnership with a community group  which must also be involved in the application process.  Funded projects must be completed by 4th March 2016.  The deadline for applications is 10th July 2015 (12 noon).  A funding application pack is available to download from: http://www.nidirect.gov.uk/road-safety-grant-scheme

Meet Merle McKeown  Barbara Hamilton  Maureen Mitchell  and Angela Small - our Macmillan Information and Support Manager based at the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast  Merle  Barbara and Maureen all volunteer at the Macmillan Centre.  They help Angela Small with the day to day operation of the service and are on hand for:  ‚Ä¢ Meeting and greeting   ‚Ä¢ Offering refreshments   ‚Ä¢ Emotional support through listening       ‚Ä¢ Providing appropriate information resources     ‚Ä¢ Signposting to other local services   ‚Ä¢ Updating information displays  ‚Ä¢ Answering telephone & completing enquiry forms  In 2014 volunteers attached to the Macmillan Information Service at the Royal Victoria Hospital  Belfast were presented with the Deborah Hutton Award at the first National Awards Ceremony for Macmillan volunteers in London.  This prestigious award is for volunteers who provide practical support and care to people affected by cancer  beyond the expectation of their role.   Commenting on the award  Angela said: ‚ÄúWith their individual and collective commitment  skills and input they are exemplary volunteers who demonstrate outstanding dedication to the aims of the service. They are truly deserving of this award!‚Äù  The Belfast Health and Social Care Trust is committed to the promotion  support and development of volunteer participation throughout the organisation.   To do this  Volunteer Co-ordinators work throughout the Trust and are responsible for volunteering opportunities in different areas and hospitals. Volunteering is a great opportunity to offer your time and skills to make a difference to people‚Äôs lives as well as for personal development  To find out more about volunteering  visit www.belfasttrust.hscni.net/about/volunteering    The Macmillan Information Service at the Royal is seeking to develop its volunteer base.  For further information and expressions of interest  please contact @Patsy McDaniel  Macmillan Locality Volunteer Co-ordinator on 028 9504 3380 or email patsy.mcdaniel@belfasttrust.hscni.net  Alternatively  you may visit the Macmillan Information Service on Level 2 or contact Angela Small  Information Manager on           028 9063 0022.

ELLIE LOUISE BROWN COFFEE MORNING RAISES ¬£12 000 for NI CANCER CHARITIES  meaning that in just one year the Ellie Louise Fundraising Appeal has raised over ¬£25 000 for cancer charities.  Little Ellie Louise  now aged four  was diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia on March 28  2012 and has been receiving chemotherapy treatment at Belfast Royal Hospital for Sick Children. She is currently over a year into her treatment which will continue until 2014.  ‚ÄúShe is so lively and bubbly. When she goes into a room she talks to everybody. She is just a breath of fresh air and is totally unaware about her illness. Her biggest priority is food on the table and playing. She is such a wee character and just loves all technology ‚Äù said her mum Fiona Brown.  Having received immeasurable support from a number of charities  Ellie Louise‚Äôs family were inspired to start a fundraising campaign to show their gratitude and raise awareness of the ‚Äòlife-changing‚Äô work they do.  What started out as an idea to hold a fundraising coffee morning has snowballed as Ellie Louise‚Äôs bravery touched the hearts of the local community. A number of schools  playgroups  clubs and even complete strangers have organised a range of events and helped the Brown family raise over ¬£10 000 in March  but the money kept coming in.  The family set up an on-line donation account and got the word out that they are fundraising for the four charities  they are the Northern Ireland Children Cancer Unit Fund  Northern Ireland Cancer Fund for Children  CLIC Sargent and Macmillan Cancer Support.  Fiona  praised the work of all the groups who she said have made the past year bearable and helped them get through the difficult times when they thought ‚Äútheir world was falling apart‚Äù.  Fiona and her husband Rodney said they are overwhelmed by the support and generosity of the local community that has saw the money raised to date now surpass the ¬£25 000 mark.  ‚ÄúCombining the amounts of this year and last year gives a very generous amount of ¬£25 790.  So it is incredible to think that your contribution has been part of the success that has achieved over ¬£25 000 in one year from the local community.  This is an amazing amount of money. I can assure you that every one of these charities do fantastic work for children with cancer and their families ‚Äù said Fiona.  ‚ÄúWe may not get a chance to personally say thanks to everyone who contributed  helped out and supported us in any way  so a big thank you to everyone. It is so humbling and overwhelming.  ‚ÄúA big thank you also to the charities for their help and continuing support.  The fundraising appeal was about raising awareness of childhood cancer and of the charities.  This was about giving something back that will ultimately benefit families like ourselves who have a child with cancer.‚Äù

The World Health Organisation released a World Cancer Report today warning of a looming Cancer Tidal Wave fuelled by alcohol  smoking and obesity. It seems half the population of the UK are also alarmingly unaware of the steps they can take to reduce their risk of cancer. What is heartening is the call for more commitment to prevention and early detection such as our Health Promotion programmes. For more information on the programmes we have available contact the team at Action Cancer House.

What a start to the week we have had here at Cancer Fund for Children. The boys were delighted to meet their rugby heroes  get autographs signed as well as share some photographs with the stars.  Speaking about the visit Gillian said   ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs fantastic to show Rory and Jacob around our therapeutic short break centre  and for them to be able to meet some of the young people who have benefitted from our support.  ‚ÄúFor the young people who are here today  the players‚Äô visit will be extra special. The Ireland team have shown that with passion  belief and team spirit  so much can be achieved. We hope to pass this positivity on to all of the young people we support.  ‚ÄúA huge thank you to them for taking the time out of their busy schedules and helping to create some very special and happy memories.‚Äù  #DreamsComeTrue #ShoulderToShoulder

We are supporting Cancer Research UK s ‚ÄòCough UP‚Äô campaign.      Right now Government cuts to public health funding means vital Stop Smoking Services are being closed down  preventing smokers accessing the most effective way to help them quit.  Smoking kills more than 100 000 people in the UK every year and the tobacco industry makes a profit of over ¬£4 000 for every death caused by tobacco.   The campaign wants tobacco companies to pay for the damage they cause by using their profits to keep Stop Smoking Services open and fund advertising campaigns to help people quit.  Watch the video below then please sign the petition at :  https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/support-us/campaign-for-us/make-the-tobacco-industry-pay-help-us-save-stop-smoking-services?t=z00a02o8

Bethany Courtney  aged 18  was diagnosed two years ago with cancer related illnesses  Aplastic Anaemia and PNH  (diseases which destroy Bethany s red blood cells) ...  Daisy Lodge is like an oasis with the trees and Mournes in the background. My stays there gave me the chance to speak to my Specialist  Gemma O Toole  about my illness. This was a big breakthrough for me as I had tried counselling before but just couldn t open up. With Gemma I felt so comfortable. It helped me see I don t have to face things alone. I would urge people to sign up to climb Slieve Donard with Cancer Fund for Children this August. The challenge could help more young people like me.    Join our Slieve Donard challenge on Sunday 30th August and ensure all children with cancer have someone to talk to. Find out more at http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/event/slieve-donard-climb-3/

With the return to school just around the corner we thought we‚Äôd share some useful tips for packing a healthy lunch box üçΩüçéüçäüçèüçâ   ¬∑ Try using a lunch box planner for the week to involve your children in planning and packing their healthy lunch boxes ¬∑ Add as much variety as you can  for example bread  pita  wraps or rolls and a range of fruit and vegetables ¬∑ Often children need to try new things many times before they will enjoy it so try new ideas at home first before adding to their lunchbox  For lots more tips on packing a healthy lunch box check out Safefood   http://www.safefood.eu/Publications/Consumer-info/Healthy-lunchboxes.aspx

Thank you so much to the team at Airporter Derry for raising the fab amount of ¬£1 500 for our new Support Centre at Altnagelvin #macmillanwesternappeal . The glamorous girls presented me with a cheque this morning but we thought we d use our lovely new numbers for photo!

‚ÄúWhen Nathanael was first diagnosed with kidney cancer it was a massive shock  we had no idea that something like this could come knocking on our door let alone be invading Nathanael‚Äôs body. We hadn‚Äôt realised that cancer didn‚Äôt discriminate against anyone  it didn‚Äôt even care that he was only a baby. We felt helpless and that there was nothing we could do to help him  cancer had took control of our lives.  ‚ÄúCancer changed our family drastically  we went from being a normal family enjoying our children and working hard to a family who felt like we were fighting each day for survival.   ‚ÄúCaitriona  our Cancer Fund for Children Specialist was amazing support during this time. When Alfie  our other son was struggling to understand why Nathanael was so sick she brought us literature aimed specifically at his age group which helped us to explain treatment gently and carefully at his level.   ‚ÄúShe also helped arrange for to stay at Cancer Fund for Children‚Äôs therapeutic short break centre  Daisy Lodge  it was the breather that we needed from hospital life and the jail that had become our own home. Not once did anyone even mention our horrible journey and what brought us there  instead the staff played games with our boys and made them feel special by giving them all the time and attention they could wish for.  ‚ÄúWe recently got the amazing news that Nathanael is cancer free. It‚Äôs the result we have been fighting for all year. We are beyond delighted and proud. We are so thankful to Cancer Fund for Children for their support during this past year. They helped us feel like a normal family even when we were going through the worst.‚Äù  This #WorldCancerDay  the Thompson family from Randalstown are sharing their story about what was it was like when son Nathanael was diagnosed with cancer aged just nine months old. The family said that thanks to the support of Cancer Fund for Children  they were able to feel like a ‚Äònormal‚Äô family again.  Read more of their story here: http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/news/world-cancer-day/  #WorldCancerDay #ChildhoodCancerAwareness #MakingADifference

BENEFIT SANCTIONS DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECT HOMELESS CLAIMANTS    Homeless people are more likely to have their benefits sanctioned according to a report published by Homeless Link.    A High Cost to Pay reports that around a third of homeless people claiming Job Seekers Allowance (JSA) or Employment & Support Allowance (ESA) have been sanctioned.  In comparison  only 3% of non-homeless claimants have been sanctioned.  Homeless Link surveyed 46 of its member organisations after members reported increasing concerns about clients‚Äô benefits being stopped.  Who is being sanctioned?  The survey found that some groups are at greater risk of being sanctioned.  These are:  ‚Ä¢ young people in receipt of JSA  ‚Ä¢ homeless people with mental health or substance use issues  ‚Ä¢ people with poor English skills  such as homeless migrants.  These findings would support other research  such as that carried out by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation  which shows that a lack of understanding of the benefits system can lead to vulnerable people losing their benefits.    Reasons for benefit sanctions    The report found that the most common reasons for respondents in receipt of JSA receiving sanctions were  ‚Ä¢ failing to participate in the Work Programme (45%)  ‚Ä¢ failing to attend an advisory interview (28%)  Respondents indicated that interviews or appointments were often missed due to ill health or conflicting hospital and other appointments.  The report set out a number of reasons why a homeless person could miss appointments in good faith  ‚Ä¢ the letter may have been delivered incorrectly  to the wrong address or the wrong hostel resident;  ‚Ä¢ homeless people with complex needs may not be able to read or understand their letters.  ‚Ä¢   The impact of benefit sanctions on homeless people and service providers  In its report  Homeless Link lists a number of problems which member organisations said arose as a direct result of sanctions.  ‚Ä¢ Homeless people are starting to build up rent arrears and service charge arrears  ‚Ä¢ Service charge and rent arrears also create financial difficulties for service providers.  ‚Ä¢ Increasing numbers of homeless people are in food poverty and are struggling to eat  ‚Ä¢ Homeless people may borrow money to cope while being sanctioned  which can lead to survival crime to pay off the debt  ‚Ä¢ Homeless people have reported increased anxiety and worsening of existing mental health issues.  ‚Ä¢   Respondents to the service felt that sanctions did not help homeless people into work and did not encourage homeless people to engage more with Jobcentre Plus.  For the full report  including methodology and response rates  download the report at; http://www.housingrights.org.uk/news/benefit-sanctions-disproportionately-affect-homeless-claimants

Study highlights major psychological impact of cancer  Cancer Fund for Children welcomes a new study that s shed light on the major psychological impact a cancer diagnosis and treatment can have. The study by Oxford and Edinburgh University researchers which was published in the Lancet  found that as the focus is mainly placed on medically treating cancer  conditions such as depression that come about as a result of the illness are often overlooked. The study provides an evidence base to support the work we have been carrying out for many years. Our wrap-around therapeutic support services address the psychological and wellbeing needs of those affected by cancer. Our services uniquely dovetail with the clinical cancer teams across the province ‚Äì and beyond. We will be focussing on this further as part of our upcoming Childhood Cancer Awareness Month Campaign in September. Keep an eye on our website next week for a more in depth discussion about this research. For more info on the study click here: http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-28954661

Today is the 1st of October which marks the first day of Breast Cancer Awareness Month!  Watch the video below as Cathy Martin  the creator of Belfast FashionWeek kindly takes a 1 Minute Mammogram to show us how it s done!  Breast screening is an X-ray of the breast. It‚Äôs carried out in women who have no symptoms with the aim to reduce deaths from breast cancer through early detection of the disease.   Action Cancer provides breast screening to women aged 40 ‚Äì 49 and 70 + who fall outside the NHS age range (50 ‚Äì 70).  You can book a breast screening appointment online at actioncancer.org or by calling 028 9080 3344.
