Give your views on our rural future  The Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) is to hold a series of consultation events to allow those who live in rural areas the opportunity to give their thoughts and views on the new Rural Development Programme (RDP) 2014 ‚Äì 2020. Anyone with an interest in the wider countryside including food and farming  environment  rural business  tourism  social enterprise  rural services  community and village regeneration is encouraged to come along and contribute to the new programme and its investment in our rural areas.   The events  hosted by DARD  will also be attended by Rural Development Council as the Rural Network for Northern Ireland  Rural Community Network  the Northern Ireland Rural Women‚Äôs Network and Rural Support Networks.   The dates and locations of the planned evening events are as follows: ‚Ä¢ Wednesday 28 August  Greenmount College  Antrim ‚Ä¢ Tuesday 3 September  Enniskillen College  Fermanagh ‚Ä¢ Thursday 5 September  Loughry College  Cookstown ‚Ä¢ Tuesday 10 September Benedy Community Centre  Dungiven ‚Ä¢ Thursday 12 September  Armagh City Hotel ‚Ä¢ Tuesday 17 September  The Lodge Castlewellan   All events will be held between 7.00pm and 9.00pm. For further information  including links to the Consultation document visit www.rdc.org.uk  or www.ruralnetworkni.org.uk

Introducing Rosemary Beare  one of our Ambassadors who is spreading awareness of the signs and symptoms of bowel cancer.  Symptoms of bowel cancer include:  -a persistent change in bowel habit  causing them to go to the toilet more often and pass looser stools  usually together with blood on or in their stools -a persistent change in bowel habit without blood in their stools  but with abdominal pain blood in the stools without other haemorrhoid symptoms  such as soreness  discomfort  pain  itching  or a lump hanging down outside the back passage -abdominal pain  discomfort or bloating always provoked by eating  sometimes resulting in a reduction in the amount of food eaten and weight loss The symptoms of bowel cancer can be subtle and don t necessarily make you feel ill.  For more info go to: http://www.nhs.uk/Conditions/Cancer-of-the-colon-rectum-or-bowel/Pages/Symptoms.aspx  Make sure to visit your GP if you have any concerns. Early detection saves lives.

NICEM 15th Annual Human Rights and Equality Conference  NICEM‚Äôs annual conference will take place on Friday  20 September 2013 at the Wellington Park Hotel  Malone Road  Belfast.  The key theme this year is the European Protection of Fundamental Rights II. This is the follow-up from last year s theme which is focus on the progress and the impacts of austerity cuts. The conference will also look at the recent political discourse on flag  emblem and parade  in addition to the usual judicial review of the year. The conference is divided into four topical areas:  Section 1: EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and European Social Charter of the Council of Europe  Section 2: Public Sector Duty: Empire strike back? Section 3: Judicial Review and Public Interests Law of the year in GB and in NI Section 4: Flag  emblem and parade: democracy  rule of law and human rights protection  For more information please contact Elizabeth Nelson at NICEM on 028 90238645or elizabeth@nicem.org.uk

Dad Ruairi Mc Cann is encouraging local people to get mucked to the eyeballs on 9th October  by taking on our Bog Run in Castlewellan Forest Park.  Ruairi and his family took on the Bog Run for the first time last year  after his brave son Jack beat cancer for the second time.  The McCann family are planning to take on the mucky 5K run again this year to give something back to the charity that supported them throughout Jack s cancer journey.  Ruairi said:   It was shortly after we found out that Jack was in remission that we decided we wanted to give something back. We could think of no better way than getting bogging  having fun  and raising vital funds for families like ours in the process. We all had a blast taking part  and can‚Äôt wait to do it all again this year!‚Äù  Help support families like Jack s by registering for the Bog Run here: http://bit.ly/2c1ZIbC

MEET LEIGH   I wish the Peer Mentoring service had been available when I was going through my treatment for cervical cancer. It s exactly what I needed.... So when the opportunity came up to train as a mentor  I couldn t turn it down. Hoping I can help even one person feel a little less alone.    Leigh is part of our Peer Mentoring Team at Action Cancer who have all had their own cancer diagnosis and who are now keen to share their experiences in such a way that it may help others along a similar journey  by listening  sharing stories  answering questions and just being there in a way that sometimes others can‚Äôt be.   If you would like to get in touch with Leigh or any of our mentors  please contact Elizabeth Boyd on 90803355/07580133757 or at eboyd@actioncancer.org

New Cancer Rehabilitation Physiotherapy Service starting in May! We are delighted to be able to offer a new Cancer Rehabilitation service to cancer patients who are suffering from fatigue or musculo-skeletal pain/restrictions.  This service provides physiotherapy to relieve pain and restrictions and 1:1 exercise training to relieve fatigue.   The service is available in Armagh and Maguiresbridge in partnership with SPARK Cancer Rehabilitation.  To avail of this service call us on 02890 803344.
Action Cancer shared a live video.

New Scar Therapy service available! Scar therapy can help relieve pain and restrictions around the area of a surgical scar. It involves very gentle massage to increase blood flow to the area. If you have had cancer related surgery in the past and are still having pain or restrictions you can avail of this service. You must have completed any radiotherapy or chemotherapy before attending.   To book an appointment call Action Cancer on 02890 803344.

Big Lottery Fund NI ‚Äì Reaching Out: Supporting Families Programme     The Big Lottery Fund today announced details of a major multi-million pound programme to support some of Northern Ireland‚Äôs most disadvantaged families.      The Reaching Out: Supporting Families programme will tackle some of the issues affecting families across Northern Ireland including addiction  poverty  mental ill-health and separation.   Supporting Families will award grants of between ¬£500 000 and ¬£700 000 to projects that will help families to improve their children‚Äôs lives by building strong and nurturing relationships. The programme will support children under the age of 12 and their families facing a range of challenges.     Projects funded will support a wide range of activities such as getting parents more involved in their children‚Äôs learning  work to reduce family isolation from the wider community and programmes that will strengthen family relationships.    There is a two stage application process.  Stage one application forms can be submitted any time between now and January 2015.  Further information on the funding programme -  www.biglotteryfund.org.uk

Sad news  We would like to pay tribute to the inspirational campaigner  Una Crudden  who has died.  Una started a one-woman social media campaign to raise awareness of the signs and symptoms of ovarian cancer  the importance of early diagnosis  and the need for equal access to the best treatment and latest advances.  She ended up in the headlines and has kept ovarian cancer in the news.  We owe a debt of gratitude to Una Crudden for her tireless campaigning and extend our sincere condolences to her family on her passing.  Here she is celebrating one of her successes with Macmillan GP facilitator  Johnny Browne  and Dr Miriam McCarthy from the Public Health Agency.

AFFECTED BY HEREDITARY CANCER AND WANT TO SUPPORT OTHERS?  We are now recruiting for our next group of mentors who will be working with people who have been affected  have had a cancer diagnosis. Our mentoring service  offers support to those who have either received a cancer diagnosis or who have been affected by the BRCA genes. The service will be offered by previous cancer patients   those at high risk and also those who have a BRCA mutation predisposing them to Breast and Ovarian Cancer.  All our mentors will be people who are able to empathise and understand fears  concerns and emotions  in a unique way that many of us cannot.   All our mentors received accredited training to enhance their current skills and abilities and are provided with ongoing support from Action Cancer when they have been matched with a client. We aim to match mentors to those who have received a similar diagnosis to themselves  however our experience to date has been that support from really anyone else who has been faced with the consequences of this disease has been valuable and so if we haven‚Äôt had an exact match  we have been working with similar experiences and background.   Training for this group will be on 3rd  10th and 17th of October and if you are interested in this  please contact Elizabeth Boyd on 028 9080 3355 or eboyd@actioncancer.org

NI Housing Executive Annual Report 2013   The Annual report of the Housing Executive for the year ended 31 March 2013 has been published. In his foreword  the Chairman Mr Donald Hoodless highlights the challenges the Housing Executive has faced in the last year and looks ahead to the continuing challenge in ensuring  a sustainable for the social housing sector.  The scale of the business and the associated services delivered in the course of the previous year are typified as follows;  ‚Ä¢ 352 957 people visited our local offices for landlord services;  ‚Ä¢ 472 990 repair requests were dealt with;  ‚Ä¢ ¬£635.7m was administered in Housing Benefit;  ‚Ä¢ Over 24 000 vulnerable people have had their quality of life enhanced through the Supporting People Programme;  ‚Ä¢ 41 356 applicants were on the housing waiting list at 31 March 2013 and 22 414 of these were classified as being in housing stress;   ‚Ä¢ 9 878 housing applicants were found to be homeless after investigation;  ‚Ä¢ 26 136 Housing Executive homes were included in planned maintenance;  ‚Ä¢ 1 379 new homes were started through the Housing Executive‚Äôs Social Housing Development Programme Group;   ‚Ä¢ 88 638 homes were managed by the Housing Executive;  ‚Ä¢ 297 tenants purchased their home;   ‚Ä¢ 1 032 private sector grant applications were approved;  ‚Ä¢ ¬£23m was invested on physical adaptations in both social and private housing to help people to remain living independently in their own homes;  ‚Ä¢ 18 000 households in Housing Executive estates are now actively involved in the Shared Neighbourhood Programme;  ‚Ä¢ 88 estates are participating in the Building Relationships in Communities programme;  ‚Ä¢ 65 Neighbourhood Officers were employed  providing a vital link with residents to address local estate issues and concerns;   ‚Ä¢ Over 400 community groups worked in partnership with us through the Housing Community Network.    The full annual report is available on the Housing Executives website at; http://www.nihe.gov.uk/2013_annual_report.pdf

Two young cousins who were diagnosed with cancer within months of each other have inspired an amazing fundraising drive for Cancer Fund for Children.  Little Thomas  son of Angela and Paul Hearty  from Lavey  was diagnosed with a grade 4 brain tumour in December 2015 and just seven months later  his cousin Hunter  son of Amy and Ryan Kelly  from Dungiven  was diagnosed with leukaemia.  Following their diagnosis  both boys had to undergo several surgeries as well as months of gruelling chemotherapy. During their stays in hospital  the boys and their families received support from Cancer Fund for Children  including availing of short breaks at our therapeutic short facility  Daisy Lodge.  Both families are now determined to give something back to say a huge thank you for the support they have received. The families recently took on our Giant Coastal Challenge event and are now looking forward to getting muddy at this weekend‚Äôs Bog Run.  Mum Angela said:  We would like to say a massive thank you to anyone who has donated so far.   Thankfully both boys are doing amazingly well and are enjoying all the childhood experiences they missed out on - normal life that is so easy to take for granted.   To read more of the family‚Äôs story and to support their fundraising  go to: https://www.derrynow.com/news/little-warriors-inspiration-major-fundraiser/186938

MONTHLY COFFEE AND CHAT  If you or anyone you know has been diagnosed with cancer and would like to chat to other people in the same boat  we would love to see you at our new monthly coffee mornings beginning TUESDAY 12th APRIL. #Factoftheday Did you know The Mourne Wall that passes over 15 mountains  including Slieve Donard  took 18 years to build? From 1904 to 1922  stonemasons worked in the mountains from March to October to build the wall that we see today. Take in some local history on our latest challenge: Climb Slieve Donard! Visit http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/event/climb-slieve-donard/ or email alex@cancerfundforchildren.com for an info pack!

When living with or recovering from cancer it can be easy to forget how capable you really are.  The HOPE course  developed by Coventry University and Macmillan Cancer Support  is designed to help people become more knowledgeable  skilled and confident in managing the physical and emotional consequences of being affected by cancer. The course is free and for individuals who have  or have had a cancer diagnosis.  It s led by people who are affected by cancer and/or health professionals.  Apply for a place on the course or find out more by getting in touch at nilearning@macmillan.org.uk or  give us a call on 028 9070 8610.

The first seven families are currently enjoying some much needed quality time together to rest  relax and recuperate.  Thank you all for your support in helping us get here today. CCRCB/Brca Link NI/Action Cancer  8th Annual BRCA Conference  We are delighted to announce that the Centre for Cancer Research and Cell Biology  School of Pharmacy  Brca Link NI and Action Cancer are organising our 8th annual patient information day for men and women at high risk of breast and ovarian cancer and their families.     The event will be held on Friday 19th January in the Balmoral Hotel  Belfast. Arrival from 9.30am for a 10.00am start  finishing about 15.30pm.   This year our main themes are: ‚ÄúResearch‚Äù  and ‚ÄúClinical Trials for Breast and Ovarian Cancer.‚Äù We will also have an  Ask the Experts  session with a panel from specialties including surgery  plastic surgery  oncology  gynaecology  genetics and fertility.     Please register for the event at: https://brcalinkni2018.eventbrite.co.uk/

Housing Rights Service Training and Online Resources  Disputes  damages and adjudication - deposit protection workshop ‚Ä¢ Derry - 14 August (afternoon) ‚Ä¢ Belfast - 15 August (morning) As of 1 April 2013  new regulations require landlords taking a deposit for a private tenancy to protect it with an approved scheme. Recently a group of young adults who have been impacted by cancer attended a training residential at Narnia Log Cabin. The group aged 18-25 are taking part in our ‚ÄòYoung Ambassadors‚Äô programme.   This new programme aims to give those young adults who have been impacted directly by a cancer diagnosis  the opportunity to develop the leadership and group work skills to assist in the delivery of Cancer Fund for Children services.  As part of the residential  they took part in a range of training sessions  such as canoeing  rock-climbing  light photography and camp craft. This provided the group with the opportunity to learn new skills so they can assist our team of Specialists to deliver residential experiences for children and young people affected by cancer.  Our Residential Specialist Marty said:  ‚ÄúAt Cancer Fund for Children  we believe it is important to invest in our young people and provide them with the opportunity to develop the necessary skills to become the next generation of leaders. The group are very passionate about their roles as young ambassadors for the charity as they enrich the support we offer young people living with cancer.‚Äù  To find out more about how we support children and young people go to: http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/how-we-help/  #YoungAmbassadors #FutureLeaders #ChildhoodCancerAwareness

‚ÄúCancer doesn‚Äôt have to change who you are.‚Äù   This is Hendrikje‚Äôs story  as told by her Cancer Fund for Children Ward Support Specialist Helen.   ‚ÄúHendrikje is an extremely bright and talented 14 year old who was recently diagnosed with cancer. I have had the joy of getting to know her and her family as they have journeyed the initial stages of diagnosis and treatment on the Children‚Äôs Ward at the Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children.    ‚ÄúHendrikje has an incredibly fun spirit so was keen to get stuck into some creative projects; we painted a vibrant canvas which represented her personality and as we were doing this  we reflected that having cancer doesn‚Äôt have to change who you are.   ‚ÄúThis canvas became a backdrop to a polaroid photo project  documenting Hendrikje‚Äôs time on the ward. We had a lot of fun taking pictures  dressing up and getting the doctors and nurses involved.   ‚ÄúBeing invited into the life-space of a young person and their family  sharing their highs and lows and getting to know them is really humbling and rewarding.‚Äù  When a teenager or young adult is in cancer treatment  it can often be a very isolating time. Frequently they are treated alongside much older patients on the adult ward  or those a lot of younger on the children‚Äôs ward.  Our Ward Support Specialist‚Äôs role is to help support these young people  discuss some of the challenges they are facing and provide them with the chance to connect with other young people who know what they are going through.  Speaking about Helen‚Äôs support  Hendrikje said:  ‚ÄúI really enjoyed Helen‚Äôs visits to the ward. I enjoyed painting the canvas and talking  it really gave me something to do and to think about other than my chemo  medicines and doctors‚Äù.   You can find out more about how we support young people with cancer here: http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/how-we-help/   #WardSupport #teenageandyoungadults #Cancerfundforchildren

Take on Action Cancers August 2017 Charity Challenge  Zip Across the River Lagan.   ‚ÄúThis year I was determined to give back to Action Cancer once my treatment was finished  I wanted to set myself a challenge. I‚Äôd come across the Zipline event on Facebook and I knew I had to do it! The date was so significant to me as on 21st April 2016 I visited the Action Cancer Big Bus in Ballymoney and on 22nd April 2017 I completed the zip line challenge across the River Lagan! What better way was there for me celebrate my one-year anniversary  almost to the day  since visiting the Big Bus? This event was perfect.‚Äù  Juliet McFarland was 45 when her breast cancer was detected on board Action Cancer‚Äôs Big Bus. One year on from her diagnosis Juliet wanted to give back to the charity that saved her life  and took her on her own challenge of zipping the Lagan.   Could you and your friends take on the zip line Charity Challenge?  Tag your nearest and dearest and sign up to this terrific event!     To read more of Juliet‚Äôs story visit;  http://ow.ly/5qAI30bwEE1    To sign up to the August zipline visit;  http://ow.ly/k2YS30bwEG1

Cancer Prevention Week  Prevent the preventable - there are many ways to reduce your risk of cancer and improve your health & well being from eating a healthy diet  to taking regular exercise  not smoking  being safe in the sun and drinking alcohol moderately.  It is down to you to make positive lifestyle choices that can help to reduce your risk of cancer. So mark Cancer Prevention Week by looking after your body and speaking with your GP if you have any concerns.
For everyone who s taking part I hope you all have a great Night In

PRACTICAL SKILLS FOR COMPLETING APPLICATION FORMS Getting your funding applications right is vital in the current climate. To ensure you have the best chance of getting those all important funds why not come along to this course and update your funding skills. This session will prepare participants at all stages of the funding application process  covering what to do before  during and after making an application. The session will also consider the typical questions asked by funders and how to answer them well. This session will be useful for fundraisers  fundraising committee members  or anyone involved in the application process. After the session  you will have an enhanced knowledge of successful funding application procedures and requirements and be more successful with funding applications. The course will be held on 26th November 2013 from 10.00am - 1.00pm  and costs ¬£50 for NICVA members and ¬£70 for non members.

To help understand the difference having a Clinical Nurse Specialist makes  Rosey Whittle  a Breast Care CNS in the South Eastern Health & Social Care Trust area explains:  I started in Breast Care nursing on the surgical wards at the Ulster Hospital more than 25 years ago  when the only existing Cancer CNS post was in breast care.  At that time I noticed that other cancer patients and their relatives weren‚Äôt getting  the expert support and information that was being provided by the Breast CNS.  This appeared to increase the levels of anxiety with other cancer patients at a very difficult and frightening time in their cancer journey.    I have now been a Macmillan Breast Care Nurse Specialist for 15 years and over the years I have seen more and more CNS roles being developed to help with different types of cancer.  Today‚Äôs announcement is really good news for staff and patients ‚Äì this will ensure more patients will have access to this invaluable expert help and support of specialist nurses.

And they are off....On Saturday morning Randal McAllister along with his good friends Paul Donnelly and Brian Calvert set off from Daisy Lodge  in Newcastle Co. Down  on their mammoth challenge to cycle a circuit of all 32 counties of Ireland in just eight days.    The 32 County Cycle challenge  is in memory of Randal s daughter Anna who passed away three years ago from a brain tumour when she was just 15 years old and also to raise funds for Cancer Fund for Children and  The Children s Cancer Unit Charity.    At the launch Randal  Paul and Brian were joined by family and friends who saw them off  as well as cyclists from local clubs who cycled the first leg of the route with them.    You can check the team s progress here http://bit.ly/32CountyCycle and donate to their cycle here http://bit.ly/32CountyCycleDonate

West Belfast Services Are you aware of our new complementary therapy services in West Belfast? Action Cancer are working with the HEART project within the Maureen Sheehan Centre (Albert St) to deliver complementary therapy to children (aged 5+) and adults impacted by cancer. Therapies on offer include: aromatherapy  gentle massage  reflexology and Bowen and Emmett techniques which are particularly beneficial in dealing with pain and restrictions. To book an appointment call Action Cancer on 028 9080 3344.

As a carer for my mother who had been through surgery and radiotherapy for cancer I felt that I was not deserving of being able to avail of Action Cancers complementary therapies.  However when I went for my first consultation I became aware of the emotional burden I was carrying and felt quite emotional when talking about the situation.  The stresses had manifested in my body as aches and pains and headaches.  The benefits I have had since attending complementary therapies are that I am more in control and feel better emotionally and psychologically.  My mother also feels better when I am happier and well and coping with life  (complementary therapy clients comments).  You also can avail of our services if you are caring for a loved one with cancer.  Just call Action Cancer on 02890 803344.

International Tourism Events Fund (Northern Ireland)  The International Tourism Event Funding Programme is designed to support events including national or international world events that have the potential to have an economic impact on Northern Ireland and attract tourists  investors and international media coverage. Funding is available to support events taking place in Northern Ireland that will impact significantly against the core criteria ‚Äì particularly those that will attract substantial international media coverage.  Applications will be open to legally constituted tourism and events organisations in Northern Ireland.  For events taking place between 1st April 2016 and 31st March 2017  the call for applications closes on Monday 16 November 2015 at 12 noon.

Meet Rosemary...   My name is Rosemary and in March 2014  I was given the news that I had cancer of the anal canal. After a series of radiotherapy and chemotherapy  I am continuing to live my life to the full and am now volunteering as a Peer Mentor with Action Cancer.   I wanted to become a Peer Mentor because I realised the importance of continued & sustained support throughout my cancer journey. I feel if I can help others at this very testing time then I can take away something positive from my own illness.   If you would like to chat to Rosemary or indeed any of our mentors  please contact Elizabeth Boyd on 9080 3355 or eboyd@actioncancer.org. Alternatively you can request this service online by clicking the link below: http://www.actioncancer.org/How-We-Help/Support-and-Therapeutic-Services/Peer-Mentoring

Minister McCausland announces the way forward for urban regeneration and community development    Social Development Minister Nelson McCausland has announced the publication of the new Urban Regeneration and Community Development Policy Framework.    The Framework will determine the priorities for urban regeneration and community development policies and programmes over the coming years. It will shape the design of projects like Royal Exchange development  Public Realm improvements in town and city centres and support disadvantaged communities.    At an event to announce the appointment of contractors for the redevelopment of Bank Square Minister McCausland said: ‚ÄúIt is very appropriate that I am announcing the publication of the Urban Regeneration and Community Development Policy Framework here in Bank Square today. This project reflects strongly one of the policy objectives contained in the Policy Framework namely to strengthen the competitiveness of our towns and cities.     ‚ÄúThe work that will be carried out here in Bank Square will help to create a vibrant shared space which can be utilised and enjoyed by all. It will contribute to the economic regeneration of the Westside area and of the wider city centre. Modern cities require initiatives like this which improve the quality of urban design and townscape thereby improving their attractiveness to residents and visitors alike.‚Äù    The Policy Framework has been organised around four objectives which aim to provide the foundation for addressing the underlying structural problems of urban areas and help in the creation of confident  competitive and connected communities.     The Framework is designed to focus on results on the ground. This will be done by placing outcomes ahead of process; drawing on a sound evidence base; responding to the priority needs of the community; and improving the co-ordination and integration of public services.    Copies of the Framework are available from; http://www.dsdni.gov.uk/ur-community-development-policy-framework.htm

Did you know that Cancer Fund for Children offers families the unique opportunity of enjoying a self-catering short break at our Cottages in Coleraine?  Families affected by cancer can benefit from a free of charge stay in one of our cosy Oak  Pine or Birch Cottages  located in the peaceful and tranquil surroundings of a development close to the River Bann  and within miles of the breathtaking scenery of the infamous North Coast of Antrim.  It‚Äôs the perfect place to relax  unwind and enjoy quality time together as a family away from the stresses of cancer  hospital visits and treatment.  A family who benefitted from a short break at the Cottages said:   ‚ÄúAs a family we really enjoyed our stay in this tranquil place.  It was a time to recharge our batteries after a very stressful time.  The break at Pine Cottage meant more than others may appreciate.  It is an essential service that to me is as important as all the medical assistance we have received.‚Äù  In the last year we have welcomed over 74 families to stay in our self-catering cottages in Coleraine.The Cottages continue to be a popular choice for families who want a private and peaceful space where they can create memories together.  To find out more about our self-catering short breaks and who can avail of them  go to:  http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/shortbreaks/self-cateringbreak/   To book a self-catering short break  please call us on 028 4372 4212.

Daisy Lodge is famous for its delicious cooking but star bakers  Christopher and Lucy McGinn from Newry  gave our chefs a run for their money when they came along to whip up awareness for Childhood Cancer Awareness Month!   Little Lucy  who has battled Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia  and her brother made and decorated three ribbon-shaped biscuits  to symbolise how each week in Northern Ireland the same number of children and young people will face a devastating cancer diagnosis.   To pledge your support for #CCAM visit: http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/donate/

Earlier we announced the fantastic news of our funding from Big Lottery Fund NI Empowering Young People  which will support our Young Shoulders Programme for children and teenagers coming to terms with a parental cancer diagnosis.  Tegan Blair  who was 11 years old when her mum was diagnosed with bowel cancer  explains how her mum s illness affected her:  ‚ÄúI felt different from my friends in school and I didn‚Äôt know what to do. I was shocked. I began to cry in the class. The teacher could see I was stressed. I felt really stressed. My grandma had to care for us when Mummy was having chemotherapy. Mummy was too sick and too tired to do anything with us. My mummy couldn‚Äôt drive and a voluntary driver had to take us to school. Everything was different. There were yellow sharp boxes in the kitchen for my mum to dispose of medical stuff and everywhere had to be very clean. I cried a lot.‚Äù  Talking about her experience of Young Shoulders Tegan said:  ‚ÄúI felt the energy as soon as I went there. We did such positive things and I had had to challenge myself often. I jumped into a river on a bouldering exercise with the group. I would never have done something like this before. The residential group work has given me confidence and I just don‚Äôt want it to end. I have now joined a sailing group in my local community and have passed my second exam.‚Äù  Thanks to the funding from Big Lottery Fund  we will be able to offer support to many more children and young people like Tegan  giving them the opportunity to share experiences and build confidence in a safe and supportive environment  at a time when they are very vulnerable.   Find out more here http://bit.ly/2bmqbfb

How much exercise do I really need to do.....?  We need to do 150 minutes of moderate intensity  (only minutes 5 days a week) or 75 minutes of vigorous intensity activity each week to reduce our risk of developing cancer and other serious disease.   Did you know?   Walking 10 000 steps every day is equivalent to;  ‚Ä¢ Doing 30 minutes of moderate exercise a day ‚Ä¢ Walking 5 miles ‚Ä¢ Burning 440kcal

Long-term Cancer Fund for Children supporter John McKeag recently celebrated his 95th birthday  and it was a more energetic affair than you might expect!   The day began at Comber parkrun with other team mates from Ballydrain Harriers  the club John has been a part of since he was a boy.   The 5km Parkrun proved to be simply a warm-up to the main feature of the day which was a 3 hour static cycle at Cordners Comber Road followed by a fabulous party surrounded by friends and family that evening!   Raising over ¬£1 500 throughout the day made it a birthday to remember fitting of this inspirational man who is always helping others.  Congratulations on an amazing total John and many happy returns from everyone at Cancer Fund for Children.  #SupporterSunday #BirthdayFundraising

Throughout the month of April  we‚Äôre asking you to make a difference to local families affected by cancer  by supporting our Gimme 5 campaign with goQradio  By signing up to donate just ¬£5 a month  you could help a young person affected by cancer enjoy a therapeutic short break with their family at Daisy Lodge in Newcastle  County Down.  A therapeutic short break gives families a safe and relaxing space where they can spend quality time together away from the stresses of cancer treatment and hospital visits.  Phil Alexander  Residential Services Manager at Daisy Lodge explains the difference that a short break at Daisy Lodge makes to families:  ‚ÄúWhen families arrive at Daisy Lodge  you can sense they are very stressed and anxious  and sometimes physically tired and exhausted. But when they leave after 3 or 4 days  you can see a change  something significant has happened. At the end of their short break you can see they leave less stressed  with a renewed sense of energy  a hope  and equipped to face whatever the future holds on their cancer journey.‚Äù  Whilst these short breaks are free to families who need them  unfortunately they are not free to provide.   That‚Äôs why we need your support so we can continue to provide these families with a place where they can spend precious time together and create special memories.  Listen in to Q Radio on Friday 28th April to hear more about you can support families  or to get involved now  simply go to: http://www.cancerfundforchildren.com/donate/

Finns det n√•gon i ditt land som √§r intresserad av teater och kultur? Eller finns det n√•gon som dr√∂mmer om att st√• p√• scenen och visa sina f√∂rm√•gor som ingen vet? Vi efterlyser akt√∂rer!  Varje land i Europa (medlemmar i EU eller Europar√•det) har m√∂jligheten att registrera upp till fem akt√∂rer  helst unga  d√§r de kan utf√∂ra sina kreativa f√§rdigheter och visa sina talanger.
